This is basically a story about an overpowered MC with a messiah complex teaching 3-4 anime stereotypes how to fight lame-looking monsters. There is a little PG fanservice here and there.
Story:
A misunderstood MC is placed in charge of misunderstood students. Throughout the series the MC holds a smug 'knew-it-all-along' attitude, which gets under (my) skin. It cannot be said that he grows as a person during the story, and only the last two-three episodes show any real character development in his students. I'm sure next season they'll be back to square one though. I guess I should note that I say that there are threestereotypes, but I think two of them are really common. The third girl thinks she is a goddess and is above training, which is pretty original to me. That being said, knowing that that's what she is, you will now be able to guess most, if not all of the things that she will say and do during the series.



(I like to know annoying quirks common to series before I start watching them, so here they are some listed out.)

Cliches

- Mascot Character: there was no annoying all-knowing talking pet in this series. The MC did a pretty good job of taking its place though.

- Hidden Power: the main character did have a hidden power, but not in the traditional sense of a main character suddenly discovering he's special and while he's weak now, he'll be the strongest someday in the future.

Fan Service

- Magical Falling (somehow end up in the 69 position or groping the girl's chest): I don't remember there being any of this.

- Perfect? Timing (opening up the door on someone changing): There was a lot of this.


Art: 

The monsters looked lame and the MC looked lame when he powered up to fight them. The characters generally had fluid motion, although I can think of some exceptions. Other than that, I should note that the anime does not have a 1990s-style animation to it. 


Sound:

Sound doesn't typically affect my enjoyment of a series too much, although if I really enjoy the soundtrack, it can have a +1 effect on my overall rating of the series. The soundtrack for this series was pretty nondescript in my opinion.


(Sound Pt 2)Voice Acting:

For voice acting, one of the few things that bother me in a series is when female characters have masculine voices or male characters have excessively feminine voices. That was not a problem in this series; however, I should note that since I found the dialogue and plot to be corny, I can't really bring myself to say that the voice acting was good. I guess I should also note that there's not a lot of English in the series, so there aren't many (if any) places for Japanese actors to butcher English pronunciation.


Other:

The MC is a bad OP character, since he gets his butt kicked and doesn't really show a lot of speed/power, particularly towards the end. Now usually, you'd like an OP MC to look cool when they go into their super-sayan equivalent. He does not. The main character looks as though the animation studio was on a low budget when they got to make him fight hard. To be fair, throughout the series, but especially towards the end the enemies they fight make it look like the story was written for 10 year olds. Maybe it was, in which case if you're a preteenager or child or want to watch something for that age range please ignore my review.

I'd like to start off with if I would recommend this anime or not.
My Recommendation: No
Overall: 5/10
This show is entirely average in my opinion, and depending on your tastes, you may even that this show is really bad. Here are my reasons why.
Story: 3/10
It is really hard to predict where the plot will go until a certain point in the anime. Even then the plot presented potential story lines that would be way better than what the producers went with. The plot still leaves many things unexplained, and as much as I would like to divulge on the plot holes, that would be spoiler territory.But if you somehow decide to give this show a go, be aware that the plot is most likely the weakest part of the show.


Art: 6/10

I would have scored this section a 5/10, but I'm a sucker for interesting looking weapons. Although some weapons(mainly minor characters) were super generic-looking and it made me wonder why our main cast(who are basically the worst of the worst, minus main male lead) got such cool looking weapons. The art style is very generic in all other cases, what was given got the job done.


Sound: 4/10

The sound is completely average, but nothing stands out really(minus the opening song, but that is my personal preference). Can't really say much because most of the sound was forgettable. 


Characters:6/10

The MC is a very generic, OP character for no reason but he had the potential for development but that was left as a plot hole that really bugs me. What pushed this rating to a 6/10 was the development of our main female cast. All three of them made some progress from when they started, albeit some can say they have seen development similar to the three characters.  


Enjoyment:5/10

I liked the art style, esp. Lecty, who was by far my personal 'best girl'. But that is completely from opinion. It's entirely average with ups and downs and most of the show got predictable.

When you make a fantasy anime, the expectance of one is to intoxicate the viewer to be pulled and drawn into the show that you're watching.  So, when you fail do things such as ADHERING TO YOUR BASE PLOT, then you a problem on your hands.  Kuusen Madoshi Kouhosei no Kyoukan, everyone.
Story: The story of Kuusen Madoushi is well, quite a mashup.  Humanity has been pushed onto the edge of near extinction.  The world has been overrun by a threat called the Devil Beetles, to the point that humanity had to relocate up into the air in floating cities.  There,students go to Magic High School in order to train to become sky wizards in order to fight off the Devil Beetle threat.  It is here where we have Kanata Age, a Sky Wizard who is also known as a "traitor" amongst the sky wizards, where he is forced to teach a trio of Sky Wizard failures to greatness.


Let me get something off my chest first.  Oh boy, another humanity pushed to the brink of near extinction to the point they have to be put into confined places to escape a threat that kills them!  Not like we haven't seen THAT twenty plus times in the past year of anime!  (Ok, rant over.)  Kuusen Madoshi is a plotline that doesn't particularly have an identity.  While completely focusing on our MC helping out the three girls that can barely use their weapons, Kuusen Madoshi completely forgets the entire plotline involving the supposed "villains" of the series.  This becomes a big hit on the series particularly because the entire threat doesn't even seem like a big deal in the end.  (The beetles only appeared once.)  In place of that, they change the entire focus of the series several times to the point that the entire base story becomes obsolete.


As for the story that we did get from Kuusen Madoshi, the plotline did do a fair bit better in that sense because while following the three girls on their road to Sky Wizard greatness, there was some character development that did make the show a little more interesting.  But even with that, there were a few things even then that had aspects of plot holes since it just conveniently seemed like they were able to do something competent while screwing around for the entire time before that.  (Very cliche development, but development nonetheless.)  


In the end, Kuusen Madoshi was a story that really...wasn't concise in either way.  From a story that at face value seemed like one about people fighting off an apocalyptic threat (from beetles, no less), to one about teaching kids how to swing a sword properly, to one about a stalker, Kuusen Madoshi ended without really much resolution to any of the overarching issues and stayed within solved some of the issues that the story presented.  It was very cliche to the point that you could guess what was going to happen next, so as a result, nothing really came as a surprise.


Overview:

+ Some character development

- Overused Plot idea

- Inconsistent with its plot

- Plot holes

- Predictable plotline


Characters: Similarly, the characters in Kuusen Madoshi are really not anyone that is noteworthy in any way except for one character who, oddly enough for a harem anime, is the MC.


First we have Kanata Age, the main character of this entire series.  As the aforementioned "traitor" to the sky wizards, Kanata is a guy that is known for being just generally lazy in nature though inversely, is oddly enough, a very good teacher.  Being put to help three misfits of the Sky Wizard Academy, Kanata spends the entire series attempting to help out these girls by teaching them the power of friendship and teamwork while also fixing up any issues about them.  He is very nonchalant about any sort of thing that goes on in the series, and always manages to keep a straight face anytime in any given situation.  He is a bit dense, and that's about as far as his character goes, but otherwise, he is probably the only good character in this series.  


Then we have the three main girls in the series; the three failures of the Kuusen Madoshi world, Misora, Lecty, and Rico.  All three of these girls follow a different trope of anime that takes up their entire character.  Misora is the tsundere, Lecty is the shy one, and Rico is the narcissist who has a pension for calling herself a goddess every five seconds she's on screen.  They do take on the mentality of appreciating help from Kanata during the series, but aside from that, that's really all there is to their characters.  They're bland, overused, and it's to the point that you don't even want to root for them because of how they act sometimes.  


And finally, we have Yuri, a girl who is known as Kanata's first disciple and kouhai.  Yuri is the other tsundere in the series and honestly, doesn't really make sense as a character.  The tsundere quality in her is so extreme to the point that it really doesn't make sense what her motive for doing anything really is.  She obviously like Kanata, but tries to get rid of him through indirect means which honestly, is so conflicting my head hurts.  


As for side characters, the rest of the cast if filled with a bunch of nobodies who really don't serve much for the series, with most of them not even serving as plot devices for the most part.  People like Kanata's old group, the head of the Sky wizard program, and a bunch of random girls whose names you don't even remember, don't really serve much of a purpose in this series at all.  The only one in this side cast that actually mattered was one guy that you would never expect to be important, who eventually, turned out to be very important, for some reason.


Overview:

+ Decent Harem MC  (This honestly surprised me)

-  Less than decent harem girls

-  Side characters didn't serve much purpose at all.


Art: The art for Kuusen Madoshi features two separate styles for the way the show is presented.  The normal artwork, and the CGI.  


As for the normal animation, Kuusen Madoshi really doesn't have anything spectacular for it.  It's a very bland color scheme that lacks any sort of depth to it coupled with average animation to boot.  It's just a moderately bright color scheme and doesn't really impart anything or is special in any way.  


In addition, Kuusen Madoshi uses a lot of CGI in order to animate out the "dangerous" Devil beetles, as well as character models in some parts.  The CGI is very glaring and overall, quite horrifying to watch.  Because the beetles are made of CGI, the entirety of the creature looks very jarring to look at and...they don't really do anything.  The devil beetles were made to just stay stationary and fly around rather than attack or do something threatening.  It was just sad to see a someone firing shots at a seemingly unmoving and unthreatening target and it made me question how these things were threatening to begin with.  In addition, they also have several character models done in CGI form.  This occurs sometimes when the characters are flying.  Rather than animating a character in-flight part of the time, the series replaces them with complete CGI models of the characters, which creates an instant clash in quality ad overall, didn't look good in any way.


Overview:

-  Bland animation

-  Poor CGI that made things look jarring


Sound: The music for this series is average at best.  There really isn't anything special about it since they're all pretty generic tracks without any memorable features to it, so there really isn't much to talk about.


Personal Enjoyment: I went into this show expecting it to be bad on the basis that the synopsis was so chock full of just...things, that the series wouldn't be able to support itself.  Sadly enough though, I was right, at least for many things.


Did I like this anime?


If not for Kanata's nonchalant personality and the latter half of the series focusing on a plot about a stalker, I would not have bothered to really continue this with any sort of hope.  Kanata himself is a breath of fresh air for this show because he does good while also being good.  While he is a bit of a dense character like a lot of other Harem MC's, he has enough credibility to him for him to end up becoming a half-decent character in my book.


What didn't I like about this anime?


Personally, I HATED the story and the characters.  The story was so predictable that any sort of development that happened really didn't faze me one bit.  In fact, I could guess what happens next episode without even watching it or trying.  The story never settled on one thing and that's what pissed me off as well.  It switched from devil beetles, to teaching some misfits, to finally focusing on a man who is obsessed with one of the females in the series for some reason.  It flip-flopped so much I didn't even know what I was watching anymore.  (Also, Rico is INTOLERABLE.  I am so tired of hearing her refer to herself as a goddess.)


Would I recommend this anime?


No, not really.  Kuusen Madoshi is a show that just goes all over the place without attempting to find a proper solution to anything it was doing really.  The characters are tired tropes from every anime ever, and the whole "humanity under threat" thing is an utter lie because everyone in that series was living their lives happily sipping tea or what have you without anything within a hundred miles threatening them at all.

Sky Wizards Academy
Similarly to how you have better things to watch, I have better things to write. So I’m gonna power through this review and give you just enough information for you to know why you shouldn’t watch this. 
VISUALS [ 3/10 ]
This show is animated... sort-of. The OP was almost good enough to be likeable, but nonetheless, the show as a whole is terrible across the board. Sky Wizards Academy has got to have some of the most generic and unspecial visual designs and artwork I’ve ever seen.
However, nothing can save this show from the incredibly inconsistent animation. From time to time, the animationsare just barely passable. Sadly, there are times where this show legitimately dips to four frame animation. Absolutely awful, in other words. SWA is filled to the brim with barely animated panning shots - doesn’t really even count as animation, does it? And to put the final nail in the coffin, the characters in this show never blink, which personally creeps me out. This whole thing is a mess and not worth the breath needed to praise it. 


SETTING [ 3/10 ]


Generic not-really-magical city, Japan. Not at all impressive or original. Whatever good background art is in this show is drowned out by the terrible animation. Sky Wizards Academy looks exactly like any other unimpressive light novel adaptation. 


PLOT [ 2/10 ]


In Sky Wizards Academy, we follow four generic cute girls and one slightly older instructor dude as they do sky wizard things, which apparently consist of sitting around in classrooms half of the goddamn time. The three newbie sky patrol girls whose names I’ve already forgotten take up most of the screen time. They supposedly train hard - mostly offscreen. The rest of the training shown is informal, with most tasks being actions anyone could follow - no wizardry required. The show tries to be clever several times with the different kinds of training that the instructor dude has the girls do, but it’s mostly just obvious stuff that anybody could have come up with. This show has no idea what direction it should go next, which is obvious by the random, disjointed series of events that take place. There is, in fact, a plot. Expect nothing more than a barebones outline of a story that the screenwriters just ran with. 


CHARACTERS [ 4/10 ]


Hooray for cardboard cutouts given screen time. We have main girl, who has average stats across the board with a little sprinkle of tsundere thrown in there. We have shy girl, who is good at pretty much everything but strongly lacks self confidence. We have godess girl, who is arrogant and thinks she’s a goddess even though she’s nowhere near hot or powerful enough. And we have love interest girl, who is in love with main guy and in the case of this show, is a tsundere. And finally: last, but certainly least, we have main guy. He’s an instructor and high level sky wizard who honestly is unbelievably average other than a slight mean streak. Not an impressive main cast at all. The villain is generic, too, and you’ll probably see him coming a mile away. 


PACING AND PRODUCTION [ 2/10 ]


As stated before, Sky Wizards Academy is quite bad in every way. No exceptions here. This show goes on for too long, plain and simple. This should have been a six episode OVA at most. The money spent on this show sincerely should have been added to a better show’s budget, and a different show should have occupied this time slot of Japanese TV. By my humble opinion, SWA should not have been produced at all. There are simply better ways to spend your time and money, be it as an anime producer or a viewer. Nobody on the entire staff of this show did their job well, except for the band that did the song for the OP and the Funimation voice actors that did an ok job with a garbage script. 

While we’re here I’ll briefly mention the soundtrack, which was boring and generic at best and weird at worst. There is a track in this show that has one or two vocalists singing a chorus that should have been edited to sound like at least ten, and it is pretty painful to listen to. It plays at some of the most dramatic moments in the show. Honestly, do I even need to keep going? The facts speak for themselves. 


STORY [ 3/10 ]


I could have written a better story than this, and you probably could have, too. As usual,  this is where we step into spoiler territory, so stop reading if you actually want to watch this show spoiler free. 

The storyline in this train wreck of a show is hard to follow, with events playing out of thin air and nothing connecting them to each other. No matter how hard Sky Wizards Academy tries, it falls flat on its face. The three girls progress by doing unusual tasks meant to teach them important life lessons. In hindsight, these scenes were probably supposed to be funny, but you get bored of bad animation and still shots so quickly that even one of my 4/10 scored shows will keep you much more entertained than this. 

Trite bullshit is how I’d describe the script of this show, and there aren’t any redeeming factors here to make up for its generic attempt at a light novel adaptation, which resulted in failure. I’ll just go down the list for you real quick, if you’d like to read more.

The fight scenes are very, very bad. Every single one of them pulls a Dragonball Z, with the characters talking more than actually fighting. The animations are rough and often off-model, and the fight direction was done by someone who has no idea how dogfights in the skies actually play out. 

Characters actually develop a little, which is the only thing holding up the script of the entire show. That said, the pacing is very slow and the show feels like it takes too many episodes to finish. And it doesn’t end. At all. 

The villain is uninteresting and unoriginal, and was clearly shoehorned into the plot so there’d be a villain to fight at the end. The girls just magically become stronger, without a lot of effort actually shown. There’s basically no development to accompany the changes that occur rapidly to a previously terrible team. 

That goes for the whole show, in fact. There is no sense of time as you watch Sky Wizards Academy. You have no idea what is happening offscreen, or how long these girls have been training, or... anything, really. This show is barely interpretable as a whole, but when you look into the finer details none of it makes any sense at all. 

I’m gonna take a moment to say what I’ve wanted to say this entire time: This is a piece-of-shit show, and no one should watch it. Done. 


OVERALL [ 2/10 ]

TL;DR:

Below-average production values, often with TERRIBLE animation

Almost no character development

This show has about twice as many episodes as it should

Many boring scenes

Comedic moments aren’t funny and fall flat

Fight scenes are very, very bad

There are no redeeming qualities of this show at all, other than it never outright insults me


I strongly recommend you look elsewhere for your anime. For other shows that are similar to this one but WAY better, look to God Eater for your action fix and Majestic Prince for your action/adventure show starring high school kids. Spoilers will be included. Don't read if you don't want to be spoiled (not that there is much spoiling).
Story: 2
So the story takes place in a world where humans have been overrun by a monster species, which may remind you of other titles like Shingeki no Kyojin and Black Bullet. So you would think that this story would be on humanity overcoming this invasion with parallel stories of internal fighting... Except that the premise of the monsters serve almost no purpose besides giving an excuse for aerial combat mages to exist. Besides the first episode and a very small part in the middle, the monster/insectthings have almost no screen time. Everything is based around E607 and their failures and for Kanata Age to train them into proper magicians. And here is where things go downhill.


Kanata Age is a very strong sky wizard who was once in one of the top divisions, but because he skipped out on some important events he became known as 'traitor' (what a terrible way to force a nickname). Initially it was interesting as we had no idea why he was called a traitor, which led me to believe that he was an anti-hero, but when it was explained the derogatory term felt so meaningless and forced that I felt bad for the other characters because of how corny they sounded when they used it. Kanata Age is one of those very powerful characters that we know very little about besides that he's powerful and that he holds a nonchalance attitude while being able to do everything correctly.


After Kanata Age is assigned to E607 it just becomes a poorly executed fanservice series. You get locker room shots, some 'accidental' gropes, maid outfits, bunny outfits and shower scenes. Kanata assigns the girls to do some activities with the purpose of training them, but never actually explains what they're learning until they figured it out themselves... now isn't that the best method of teaching. All of this works up to the next subplot where the girls need to enter a tournament against every other division and win or they're disbanded. I expect you know the results already.


So here we are, at ep 11 and they've won and now there's this bad guy who's in love with Yuri and what's to kill her/rape her/convert her??? (as he infected himself with monster gene to make himself stronger) At this point I don't even know what the 'bad guy' wants to do. 


And ep 12 was pretty predictable from ep 11. Obviously Yuri would be the one to defeat the bad guy except it was surprising that Kanata barely did anything this episode. And for whatever reason, the bad guy is left to live and possibly repent but from the way this series concludes, it's almost as though nothing could have happened and it would be any different, since they don't move up in rank or anything.




Art: 7

I found Misora and Yuri quite moeh, so that's why the art is what it is. There's nothing integrally wrong with the art, it's industry standard, but the animations with the weapons feel absolutely weak. It clearly lacks power and you can even see the lacklustre striking from the OP itself.




Sound: 4

OP and ED are pretty boring, the voices of the characters themselves are almost cliche and there's not much ambient noise.




Character: 1

I can't even be bothered writing out why each character is terrible so I'm just going to do a few paragraphs instead.


So Kanata Age is another unexplained male protagonist with great power who doesn't utilize it ever because he's too busy being nonchalant and vague... except when he needs to save a girl and get them to blush even more than they already do. And, as expected, the girls fall for him just because he exists (well two of them). 


Now here comes the E607 girls. You have the shy girl, the hot-headed girl and the arrogant girl, who can't stop repeating how she's a goddess. There are some flashbacks to explain their personalities but it's either so cliched or shallow that you don't even care why they are who they are. 


The other characters are almost redundant and could probably be replaced by generic characters.




Enjoyment: 4

Okay, so here's the biggest problem. The fighting and the talking seem to work independently of each other. When they're fighting, there's no dialogue, when they're talking, the action suddenly stops as if so everyone can listen in on what's being said. This breaks the flow of combat and it makes the whole thing flow so slowly.


The only redeeming feature this show has is its cute girls and that's basically it.




Overall: 3

If you're looking for fanservice, this will not sate you. If you're looking for a good story, it was left back at the introduction. If you're looking for character development, it has as much character introduction as telling your name to another person. If you're looking at how not to write a story, you've probably come to the right place.
